utterances: If he leaves orders to destroy it in his will, I don't think that we have a right because it's art to read it.
Imagine all the work that was done that we never knew about.
You know, I have the magazine, the New Yorker from '65, with the last story in it.
And I really treasure that, and I love Salinger's writing.
But I, you know, we don't have a right to every single thing he does if he doesn't want us to read it.
Yes.
I - I mean, I tend to agree.
And I - but I wonder what will happen if he doesn't leave any - if he doesn't leave any orders that it should be burned or something, I think the estate has the right to publish it.
But I...
Don't you think a man of his cunning - I think he's cunning - is clever enough to let us know by doing that that, okay, I'm dead, you can read it now?
I hope so.
I see him vomiting blood a lot.
He was vomiting blood?
I mean, he created this wonderful (unintelligible) - Holden Caulfield and that text and ""Franny and Zooey."" And you look at that and you say my goodness.
And if he brings in anything else, and it's of a lesser nature in his eyes, he doesn't want that fall, I don't suppose.
I mean, I think he's - I understand exactly why he's reticent, I really do.
And I respect his privacy.
And I think any man that has gone - is reclusive for as long as he's been shows an enormous of sanity, in light of the exploitation in the beginning.
(Soundbite of dogs barking)
Sorry about the dogs.
Well, you have to admire him for that because he could be, you know, the biggest celebrity writer around if he wanted celebrity.
And he clearly - that's not what he's doing it for.
He's doing it for the pure satisfaction of crafting a beautiful sentence or a beautiful story.
Maureen, thanks very much.
I agree.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
We're talking with Ron Rosenbaum of Slate about J.D.
Salinger.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
James(ph) is with us, calling from Denver.
What's that?
You're on the line, James.
Hello.
My question is more literary, I guess.
You know, the saga of the Glass family is such better fiction than ""The Catcher in the Rye."" I've never understood why ""Catcher"" is seen as sort of Salinger's most important work.
It doesn't seem like it is.
What do you think about that?
Well, I have mixed feelings about late Salinger.

I find the stories about Seymour, the supposed saint who committed suicide, of the Glass family, the older brother of the Glass family - I find Salinger sort of driven more and more to write less and less convincingly about why Seymour is a saint, throwing in lots of Buddhist and Eastern mysticism but not necessarily impressing me that this guy was a saint.

And I think that Holden - that ""The Catcher in the Rye"" is underrated because people misread it, because people read it only as if it reflects the point of view of Holden Caulfield and therefore is naive and over-romantic and purist and looks down upon the world, where I think that Salinger is actually creating a character who is like that, and doing so with great fidelity.
And maybe we learn something from the lesson of what it - where you end up if you reject the world for slight impurities or reject people for slight impurities.
Well, I think I'll have to read ""Catcher"" again as an adult.
Thank you for that insight.
Thanks for the call, James.
Email, we got several along these lines, from Dana(ph) in Lafayette, Louisiana.
Perhaps it's heartless of me but I can't help roll my eyes when people salivate over Salinger.
Sure, I loved ""Catcher,"" too, but Salinger seems uninterested in the public reading his later works.
He's obviously not writing it for me, to enrich the literary world, to share.
It's kind of a pretentious turnoff to me.
And let's get one last caller in.
This is Steve(ph).
Steve with us from St. Louis.
Yeah.
Hi.
I think that if Mr. Salinger doesn't want to publish his works that are unpublished, that's fine.
But the idea of locking up a character like Holden Caulfield, or Romeo and Juliet, or, you know, Mickey Mouse is preposterous.
I think that eventually once somebody publishes a work and it goes out and they get copyright protection and all of that, eventually the characters in that work become part of public culture.
And maybe if the public misreads his novel and thinks that Holden is a certain way, you know, the public should have a right to take that reading.
There's no reason why an author should have to -have the right to exert total control over that work, especially when there's probably some public value to reading things in different ways.
And those are the lawyers from the Disney company on the other line.
(Laughing) But Ron Rosenbaum, go ahead.
I wouldn't disagree that he doesn't have any formal or legal right to control the character, although the judge has seemingly granted him that.
I'm not sure I'd even agree with the judge.
And I think I tend to agree with the caller in the sense that, you know, there may not be any enforceable right.
But I can understand emotionally why Salinger would resent the hijacking of one of his great creations by someone.

I mean, I haven't - I don't want to judge the so-called copycat Holden Caulfield sequel book because I haven't read it, but, you know, I could understand why Salinger might think of it as a hijacking.
Steve, thanks very much for the call.
Thanks.
And Ron Rosenbaum, thank you for your time today.
Thank you.
Ron Rosenbaum, with us from New York.
He's a columnist at Slate.com, the author most recently of ""The Shakespeare Wars."" You can find a link to his essay ""Save the Shakespeare Wars"" on our Web site at npr.org/talk.
SCIENCE FRIDAY.
I'm Ira Flatow.
How many times have you witnessed someone who has collapsed and stood by wishing you had the training to give CPR?
Well, according to new guidelines from the American Heart Association, there is no reason now not to take action.

If you see an adult collapse and you aren't trained in CPR or you aren't confident that you can perform CPR correctly, you can do the sort of stripped-down version called hands-only CPR where you do just the chest compressions.
The Heart Association says hands-only CPR can save lives.
These new guidelines might spur people who are reluctant to do mouth-to-mouth breathing on a stranger to take action or just feel like they may make the situation worse.
They are the greatest currency manipulators ever.
(BOOING)
After two weeks of tests, Yia Mua was diagnosed with liver cancer caused by untreated Hepatitis B.
He died six months later.
Mua was born in Laos.
The HB virus is common there, as it is in most of Asia.
Many immigrants from the region contract the virus from their mother during birth.
The majority of the patients with Hepatitis B do not have any symptoms.
So, that's the major issue.
Sheik recently conducted a study of Hep B rates in the Fresno Hmong community.
They're high.
The national infection average sits at just about one percent.
It's markedly higher for Asian Americans at 10 percent, with most of those carriers being foreign-born.
But according to Sheikh's research, recently published in the journal of Community Health, that number jumps again to 17 amongst the largely immigrant Hmong community.
Hmong people might be having more infections as compared with the rest of the Asian population because they are more secluded and isolated community.
Sophia DeWitt oversees health initiatives at the Fresno Interdenominational Refugee Ministries, a social service organization.
If 17 percent of the community in Fresno County is likely to be Hep B positive and most of those who are infected aren't aware of their status, clearly there's more that needs to be done.
DeWitt says canvassing and educational outreach efforts have been somewhat successful.
Now, her and other health workers are trying to marry the Hmong's cultural beliefs with traditional Western medical care.
Basically, they're saying, you can see a doctor, get immunized and keep your folk medicines - but that's a tough sell.
(SOUNDBITE OF PEOPLE SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE)
Down the street from DeWitt's Fresno office at the golden bowl Asian market, there is a family shopping for herbs.
Kathleen Ying is 17 and she says her mother's been using chutes, herbs and vegetables to make medicines for most of her life.
It's like tea.
It's fresh.
It's, like, fresh.
